7.00.text: an elegant arc held taut by string.

10.45.text:
An effective tool in its own right, but also
beyond that - a potent symbol:

18.20.text:
Something evocative of heroes, ancient battles
and far-away fantasy;

25.61.text:
The bow and arrow is an historical weapon
common to most cultures around the world.

30.87.text:
Found in many forms, and performing many roles
- it is nonetheless instantly recognisable.

37.75.text:
So - how long has the bow been a part of human
history?

45.79.text: With whom is archery most strongly associated?

48.74.text:
And why does such a basic weapon remain relevant
today?

56.30.text:
Our story begins in a time before stories
began:

63.95.text:
The first sparks of technology - fire, pottery,
stone tools - and weapons.

71.81.text:
The bow emerged somewhere between the Upper
Paleolithic and Mesolithic era - some 25 to

80.04.text:
Hand-flung arms like spears and darts were
effective, but exploiting the elastic energy

84.52.text:
in a flexible limb made projectiles fly faster
and farther.

88.53.text:
The first intact bows date to 9000 BC, preserved
in the anaerobic bogs of Holmegaard, Denmark.

99.07.text:
Given the fragile nature of evidence, an exact
origin is impossible to pin down - but one

106.57.text: By the end of the Ice Age, everyone had them.

114.61.text:
The bow's entry into culture begins with cave
paintings - animals and hunting were a common

120.99.text: theme: along with the tools used.

124.15.text:
However, in a contemporary sense the prehistoric
use of bows is seldom shown - the stereotypical

131.69.text: 'caveman' is far more likely to wield a club.

136.85.text:
To be fair, the Stone Age does span over 3
million years - and bows occupy only a tiny

142.89.text:
sliver of that towards the end: but even so,
prehistory in culture is no stranger to anachronism.

149.75.text: But what's a few million years between friends?

155.13.text:
Turok: Dinosaur Hunter ticks a few boxes - a
time-travelling Native American fighting dinosaurs

163.30.text:
in prehistory: and while its bow certainly
feels at home, it's far from authentic.

172.37.text:
Such inaccuracy is par for the prehistoric
course: there's almost always some form of

177.10.text:
hand-waving - either with time-travel or some
other science-fiction magic.

182.90.text:
And so while not without flaw, Far Cry Primal's
attempt at authenticity is refreshing.

189.98.text:
It settles on a specific time, and a specific
place - instead of conflating millions of

195.21.text:
years of progress and different cultures scattered
across the globe.

199.54.text:
By 10,000 BC in Central Europe, the bow was
widespread - an essential inclusion for the

214.17.text:
As man settled cities and civilisation rose,
the trappings of primitive living were shed

222.08.text:
Pliant by nature, it had transformed from
a simple hunting tool into a weapon of war

227.18.text: - and archery was now a martial art.

232.73.text:
When fielded en masse, bowmen were particularly
effective against enemy infantry in formation

236.97.text:
- raining down a hail of arrows, culling numbers
and destroying morale.

244.00.text:
Equally effectively employed on horseback
- highly-mobile cavalry archers capable of

249.10.text:
flanking and harassing opponents while remaining
out of harm's way.

255.01.text:
Such tactics would shape the world to the
will of those who wielded them effectively.

259.85.text: It was the birth of strategy: the art of war.

265.89.text:
With bow in hand, battles were fought: wars
waged, and empires crumbled; and from this

277.96.text:
Every culture has their own mythology: but
the themes unite us all.

283.86.text:
Tales of epic hunts, grand victories - and
heroes: mortal acts magnified and aspects

290.57.text: of life personified in the creation of deities.

294.85.text:
For example: Artemis, the Greek goddess of
the hunt; or the Roman equivalent, Diana.

302.54.text:
Often associated with wild animals, femininity
and elegance, depicted with nocturnal bow

311.45.text:
Apollo was her brother: a central god responsible
for a wide variety of things: including the

317.46.text:
sun, medicine, knowledge, the arts, and archery:
wielding his silver bow.

325.76.text:
Seen similarly armed: Cupid, whose bow represents
the striking power of desire; the Norse pagan

332.86.text:
god Ullr; the Persian hero Arash; Yoruban
spirit Ochosi; and Hindu Rama and Arjuna.

345.69.text:
Each sprung from a primitive seed, these iconic
figures were graven cornerstones of ancient

350.54.text:
culture - and amongst the symbols that represent
them: an iconic arm.

358.08.text:
Even after all this time, the ancients resonate
in modern media: from the divine cast seen

364.02.text: in the God of War series...

366.46.text: to the cross-cultural pantheon of Smite.

370.48.text:
These myths run deep - stories retold countless
times, woven into our cultural fabric - and

383.73.text:
The bow and arrow has a broad history - but
for most, it evokes the medieval era: kings,

392.99.text:
For (most of) the old world, this is where
nations begin - and perhaps why the middle

399.93.text:
ages are particularly resonant: it's our formative
years, an origin story.

407.98.text:
Moulding the modern world was not entirely
tranquil, of course - and as with so much

413.24.text:
of human history, the exact borders were defined
by war.

419.09.text:
Even during peacetime, the logistics and preparation
for conflict shaped our society:

425.46.text:
Archers were a valuable commodity; as were
the Yew trees used to make fine

429.61.text:
bows; and the skilled bowyers, fletchers and
stringfellows who crafted them - an entire

436.18.text: industry, and a lifetime of training.

440.94.text:
An endeavour not without impact: The influence
of archery in battle can be decisive - such

446.00.text: as the events at the Battle of Hastings.

450.31.text:
In 1066, Harold II, the incumbent king of
England, was attempting to repel a Norman

455.14.text: invasion and challenge to his crown.

459.50.text:
The stories say he was killed by an arrow
to the eye, marking the end of Anglo-Saxon

463.95.text:
reign - and a victory for William The Conqueror,
commemorated in the Bayeux Tapestry.

470.80.text:
After all, no song is sung louder than that
of victory, and such historical events inspired

476.50.text:
ballads, songs & poems - forming a national
culture.

483.36.text:
English texts are full of such tales: from
the Arthurian legend, with the knight of the

488.67.text:
round table Tristan - and his unerring bow
Fail-not;

493.31.text:
to another folk hero of quite some repute
- clad in Lincoln green.

500.20.text:
Robin Hood is perhaps the most famous allegorical
archer - a heroic outlaw who lurks in Sherwood

506.65.text: Forest amongst a band of merry men.

510.00.text:
His skill with a bow was a defining trait:
whether winning tournament with shaft-splitting

515.85.text:
ability - or loosing arrows from treetops,
stealing from the rich to give to the poor.

522.89.text:
His adventures began in medieval ballads - and
in the spirit of folk literature, the gests

529.52.text:
of Robin Hood have been told and retold over
the centuries, in a wide variety of forms.

535.88.text:
Not bad for someone who doesn't exist - but
there's far more to the fictional middle ages

542.34.text: than a few men in green hose.

548.93.text:
Fantasy takes our history and morphs it into
a medieval mythology, a parallel world ready

558.16.text:
Tolkien's 'The Lord of The Rings' is an important
work here - drawing influence from earlier

563.06.text:
romantic fiction, folk tales and ancient mythology
- binding them into a single tome of great

571.69.text:
Legolas, the most renowned archer of the Third
Age, is the most prominent bow-using character

578.61.text:
(although archery is far from an uncommon
practice in Middle Earth).

586.40.text:
Fantasy fiction enjoyed a surge of mainstream
popularity in the 1960s - and the domain of

591.67.text:
swords and sorcery also provided the perfect
avenue for interactive exploration.

598.93.text:
Dungeons and Dragons in 1974 brought fantasy
to table-top gaming, formalising the characters,

605.18.text:
classes, combat and creatures necessary to
craft an imaginary world.

611.96.text:
The gameplay rules codified in D&D - not to
mention its popularity in academic circles

616.90.text:
- were key factors in the early popularity
of fantasy role-playing video games.

622.69.text:
CRPGs have had an enduring history - they've
always been a staple genre for the PC, where

632.33.text:
From the earliest text-based such as Rogue,
to the simple-top down graphics of Ultima

637.25.text:
and its clones, the bow has nestled neatly
amongst the usual set of medieval weaponry.

644.62.text:
As technology evolved, so too did the games:
with the advent of 16-bit machines, psuedo-3D

650.79.text:
games like Dungeon Master and Eye of the Beholder
gave players a taste of first-person dungeon

657.44.text:
And the ascent of the PC's golden age saw
the transition from isometric graphics to

665.83.text:
Despite the huge cosmetic differences over
the genre's lifespan, the setting, the skills,

670.54.text:
the rules - and the weapons - all remain largely
unchanged.

675.74.text:
The bow is a familiar sight across almost
all of them.

682.49.text:
Dexterity-focused, it's found in the hands
of either the swift or the deceitful - to

688.65.text:
evade the fray and keep good kiting distance
requires either speed, stealth or a means

697.25.text:
Rogues, rangers and marksmen are an essential
corner of the RPG trinity: a complement to

703.79.text:
both warrior and mage - and the scaffolds
put in place by D&D at their core.

712.70.text:
Today, fantasy remains very much en vogue:
Over the last decade there have been a number

718.14.text:
of successful franchises: the film adaptation
of the Lord of The Rings trilogy; Harry Potter;

727.37.text:
The genre has the ability to reach all kinds
of audiences - from the rule-hungry hardcore,

737.57.text:
After all, the medieval setting is quite liberating
- a chance to cast off the drudgery of modern

743.91.text:
life, indulge in the imagination of our ancestors,
and romp through a land distant - yet somehow

753.76.text:
By the start of the modern age, the bow was
largely obsolete - exploiting the explosive

761.74.text:
energy of gunpowder made projectiles fly faster
and farther.

767.93.text:
It was the advent of the firearm - leaving
behind those who clung to tradition: the rifle

773.93.text:
was both a more reliable hunting tool - and
a more deadly weapon.

780.66.text:
The bow was no match - a fact fatal to the
native Americans upon the arrival of European

789.41.text:
With no history to call their own, industrious
settlers driven by destiny headed west to

798.76.text:
A new nation was forming, and its frontiers
were defined by conflict.

805.37.text:
The Western is the American equivalent of
fantasy fiction - an exploration of their

812.37.text:
The stories of Cowboys and Indians are often
far more romantic than the reality: they tend

818.38.text:
to be scant on gruesome detail, and more heavy
on stereotype.

824.92.text:
A six-shooter for one side, and for the other:
a bow.

827.61.text:
The odds were always stacked in the cowboy's
favour, and Hollywood played obvious favourites

840.05.text:
Where European legends held bow or sword,
the firearm would become a core part of America's

845.40.text: identity: and their folk heroes reflect this.

849.28.text:
On every poster, in every shoot-out: the revolver
or rifle was the star of the show, with the

856.90.text: humble bow playing a supporting role.

864.63.text:
Despite the march of technology, there are
still those who see the importance of keeping

868.92.text:
a tradition alive - and refuse to let archery
become a lost art.

875.31.text:
Kindled by a romantic revival, and kept alight
by Olympic flame - it lives on as a modern

880.82.text: sport, and is practiced worldwide today.

887.78.text:
Hunting is another pursuit where the bow still
finds sporting purpose.

892.24.text:
Part of its appeal lies in the physical challenge
of using the bow, and the shot placement required

896.87.text:
for a clean kill - but the primitive nature
of the weapon is also a factor.

902.95.text:
And so the bow has managed to retain a niche
role - but also, and perhaps more importantly,

909.55.text: it remains relevant in popular culture.

915.21.text:
One of the most significant appearances of
the bow in a contemporary setting is in classic

919.52.text: 80s action film, Rambo: First Blood Part II.

923.07.text:
While there's no shortage of machine guns
or explosions, the bow plays an important

928.89.text:
role: a symbolic representation of the protagonist's
reversion to primitive instincts;

934.98.text: not to mention a neat gimmick.

938.88.text:
It was a distinctly masculine era for the
action genre - between Schwarzenegger, Van

944.01.text:
Damme and Stallone, there was no shortage
of muscle-bound struggles for survival.

951.50.text:
Rambo demonstrated that the bow could take
centre stage, even when surrounded by firearms

959.01.text:
- and since then, it has become a symbol for
those with the odds stacked against them.

965.91.text:
Survival-themed video games have enjoyed a
prolonged bout of popularity, largely thanks

971.98.text:
to the undying trend of zombies - and open-ended
games like Minecraft.

978.80.text:
The themes are surprisingly similar across
all of them - flung empty-handed into an unfamiliar

984.30.text:
world, suddenly reliant on whatever supplies
you can scavenge - or improvise.

991.00.text:
Some wood, some fibre, some feathers - crafting
a bow and some arrows is often a priority,

998.37.text:
as an initial ranged weapon and stepping stone
to more powerful options later.

1005.80.text:
Firearms are not always preferable, however
- the bow has certain advantages that suit

1014.21.text:
While not entirely silent, loosing an arrow
is far softer a sound than gunfire - and so

1020.52.text: the bow lends itself well to stealth in games.

1026.16.text:
This isn't a recent trait - the archer has
long been associated with hidden huntress,

1031.13.text:
or elusive rogue - but it's one amplified
in a contemporary sense by the alternatives.

1039.66.text:
This focus on stealth can help enhance a feeling
of vulnerability: with each arrow taking considerable

1046.46.text:
time to ready, and a parabolic trajectory
to consider - there's a lot at stake with

1052.57.text:
Not all games are so punishing - some present
the bow as part of a smorgasbord of weapons,

1061.63.text:
giving the player free reign to indulge in
whatever approach they desire.

1067.00.text:
Take enemy sentries out one by one with methodical
precision, or unload with a machine gun and

1072.02.text:
rocket launcher - an indulgence in pure escapist
fantasy.

1077.21.text:
In a page taken from the Rambo films, bows
have even crept into a modern military setting:

1085.80.text:
typically compound bows furnished with carbon
fibre and festooned with pulleys.

1091.80.text:
It's not entirely without real-world precedent
- there are some examples of recent military

1096.04.text: bow use, but it's far from common.

1100.64.text:
Despite this, a high-tech bow doesn't feel
too out of place on the battlefield: there's

1105.84.text:
something timeless about it that lets it slip
into almost any scenario.

1112.01.text:
It's instantly familiar, and evocative of
the entire breadth of human history - the

1117.64.text:
bow is a fundamental part of us, a link to
our ancestors and an instrument that helped

1123.26.text: create the world in which we live today.

1127.56.text:
Perhaps that is what makes it such a compelling
weapon: it speaks to something primitive within

1132.83.text: us, underneath the veneer of civilisation.

1138.09.text:
After all, with only twenty-four hours and
two meals away from barbarism:

1142.49.text:
we have more in common with the caveman than
you think.

1147.06.text:
From troglodyte to time-traveller; toxophile
or thief.

1166.18.text:
Dungeon-delvers and dragon-slayers, rogue,
ranger or elf;

1175.51.text:
No other weapon fills such a broad role, nor
is any other ingrained as deeply into human

1185.16.text:
Such a simple thing, and yet its effect could
not be more profound.

1204.27.text:
Thanks for watching - and until next time,
farewell.
